characteristics: High banking loads right-side tires heavily
Concrete surface provides high grip but is abrasive
Tire management critical for longer runs

oversteer.description: Car is loose - rear end wants to come around, especially on throttle application
principles: Increase rear grip to stabilize car
Lower rear tire pressure increases contact patch and mechanical grip
Softer rear springs allow more tire compliance
Lower track bar shifts rear roll center, loosening the car

tire_psi_rr.effect: Increases contact patch and mechanical grip at corner exit

track_bar_height_left.effect: Shifts rear roll center, adds rear grip

understeer.description: Car is tight - pushes or plows, won't turn
principles: Increase front grip to improve turn-in
Lower front tire pressure for more contact
Adjust weight distribution to favor front

tire_psi_rf.effect: Improves right-front grip (heavily loaded at Bristol)

cross_weight.effect: Transfers load to front, helps turn-in

bottoming.description: Car bottoms out or hits the track, especially in corners
principles: Increase spring rates to support the car
Balance aero load with mechanical support

spring_rf.effect: Critical at Bristol due to high banking

poor_traction.description: Car spins tires or loses traction on corner exit

tire_psi_rr.effect: Optimize contact patch vs tire stiffness

tire_psi_lf.name: Left Front Tire Pressure
tire_psi_lf.effect: Higher = more responsive but less grip. Lower = more grip but slower response

tire_psi_rf.name: Right Front Tire Pressure
tire_psi_rf.effect: Critical at Bristol - heavily loaded due to banking

tire_psi_lr.name: Left Rear Tire Pressure
tire_psi_lr.effect: Lower = more mechanical grip, but can overheat

tire_psi_rr.name: Right Rear Tire Pressure
tire_psi_rr.effect: Critical for corner exit - balance grip vs tire wear

cross_weight.name: Cross Weight Percentage
cross_weight.effect: Higher = more turn-in bite, but can cause tight condition mid-corner

track_bar_height_left.name: Track Bar Height (Left Side)
track_bar_height_left.effect: Higher = tighter car, Lower = looser car. Shifts rear roll center

spring_lf.name: Left Front Spring Rate
spring_lf.effect: Stiffer = less body roll, more responsive. Softer = more mechanical grip

spring_rf.name: Right Front Spring Rate
spring_rf.effect: Most critical spring - heavily loaded at Bristol

spring_rr.name: Right Rear Spring Rate
spring_rr.effect: Balance between support and mechanical grip

setup_principles: Bristol requires aggressive setups due to high banking and short track
Right-side components (RF, RR) are heavily loaded - often 2x left side
Tire pressure is the quickest adjustment for fine-tuning
Spring rates provide platform stability but can hurt mechanical grip if too stiff
Cross weight affects turn-in but can cause mid-corner problems if too high
Track bar is powerful for rear balance but affects car differently through corner phases
